thread.title: Following embassy opening, United Airlines eager to begin Cuba flights
thread.title_full: Following embassy opening, United Airlines eager to begin Cuba flights

author: Lewis Lazare
title: Following embassy opening, United Airlines eager to begin Cuba flights
text:
Enlarge Monday was potentially a very good day for United Airlines CEO Jeff Smisek and theâ€¦ more Chicago-based United Continental Holdings Inc. (NYSE: UAL) congratulated both the United States and Cuban governments on the historic reopening of their respective embassies in Washington, D.C., and Havana, Cuba, on July 20. That significant diplomatic development marked a further warming of relations between two countries that had broken off ties more than 50 years ago. Now that President Barack Obama has said Cuba and the U.S. can be friends again, United Airlines is wasting no time suggesting that's just fine with the airline, too. United was one of the first U.S. airlines to express its eagerness to fly between the two countries back in January . So don't be surprised if United rushes to start flights between the U.S. and Cuba just as soon as the necessary government approvals are in place. How long could that take? Probably a minimum of six months. But maybe longer. We've got 50-plus years of bad blood to deal with, remember. When United does launch regular service between the U.S. and Cuba, the lucky United hubs to get the first flights between the two countries likely will be Houston and New York City/Newark. A United spokesman indicated "we look forward to providing our customers service to Cuba from our global gateways in Newark and Houston." Subject, of course, to that aforementioned government approval. 
Want Houston Travel   Home of the Day
